title: 5 fun facts about Tower Records
text:
Tower Records documentary premieres in Sacramento 5 fun facts about Tower Records UPDATED 12:02 AM PDT Oct 24, 2015 
Tower Records is back in Sacramento -- at least for the weekend. Related Teacher accused of having... 
In honor of the new documentary "All Things Must Pass," which chronicles the record store’s rise and fall, the old store on Broadway was renamed Tower Records through Sunday. 
The film made its Sacramento premiere at the Tower Theater Friday night -- with 550 former employees attending. In addition to Sacramento, the documentary is already playing in New York and Los Angles. Soon, it’ll be released in more theaters across the country. 
More than 500 people attended the Tower Records documentary "All Things Must Pass" on Friday, Oct. 23, 2015 at Tower Theater in Sacramento. Tom Miller/KCRA Photos 
More than 500 people attended the Tower Records documentary "All Things Must Pass" on Friday, Oct. 23, 2015 at Tower Theater in Sacramento. Tom Miller/KCRA 
Movie goers will learn a lot about the international record store chain. Here are five fun facts about the iconic business: 
1) Tower Records' first store opened in Sacramento in 1960. 
2) Tower Records’ founder Russ Solomon first sold records out of his father’s Sacramento drug store. 
3) At its peak, Tower Records had 200 stores in 30 countries -- on five continents. 
4) In 1999, the company made $1 billion. 
5) Foo Fighters front man Dave Grohl is a former Tower Records employee. 
More than 500 people attended the Tower Records documentary "All Things Must Pass" on Friday, Oct. 23, 2015 at Tower Theater in Sacramento. Tom Miller/KCRA Photos 
More than 500 people attended the Tower Records documentary "All Things Must Pass" on Friday, Oct. 23, 2015 at Tower Theater in Sacramento. Tom Miller/KCRA 
The film’s star, Solomon said when the filmmakers first approached him about making a movie, he thought they were crazy. 
“I told them they were nuts,” Solomon said. “Totally crazy. Why would you ever do a movie and who would come to see it? Well they finished it -- took them a long time, but they finished it. And, a lot of people seemed to like it so far. I mean how good can it get?” Tags Sacrament Tower Records music records

FROM TOWER THEATER TO TOWER RECORDS, BOTH TRANSFORMED INTO A BEKINS -- BEACOPNS OF A SACRAMENTO SUCCESS STORY. ONE THAT IS NOW BEING TOLD ON THE BIG SCREEN. THE NEW DOCUMENTARY, "ALL THING MUST PASS," FOLLOWS THE 46-YEAR HISTORY OF TOWER RECORDS. ONCE THE LARGEST RECORD RETAIL CHAIN IN THE WORLD, ONE THAT HAD A PROFOUND INFLUENCE ON HOW PEOPLE LISTENED TO MUSIC. ITS STAR, TOWER FOUNDER RUSS SOLOMON, CALLED THE FILMMAKERS CRAZY WHEN HE FIRST MET THEM. TOTALLY CRAZY. WHY WOULD YOU EVER DO A MOVIE AND WHO WOULD COME TO SEE IT? TOM: LIKE TOWER RECORDS, PRODUCER SEAN STUART IS FROM SACRAMENTO. AFTER HEARING THE COMPANY'S STORY, HE HAD TO SHARE IT. WE KNEW PEOPLE CARED, THEY CARED ABOUT THIS COMPANY, THEY CARED ABOUT WHAT THIS COMPANY PROVIDED -- THE MUSIC, THE ENVIRONMENT, THE ENERGY. IT WAS A BIG PART OF PEOPLE'S LIVES. TOM: FOR STUART, THERE'S ONLY ONE REVIEW THAT MATTERS. THE MAN WHO STARTED IT ALL SAYS THE FILM DOESN'T MISS A BEAT. THEY PICKED UP THE SPIRIT OF THE THING AND THE SPIRIT OF THE INDUSTRY, SO THAT MAKES IT A GOOD FILM FOR THAT REASON ALONE. TOM: RIGHT NOW, THE DOCUMENTARY IS ONLY PLAYING IN THREE CITIES -- NEW YORK, LOS ANGELES, AND HERE AT THE TOWER THEATER IN SACRAMENTO, BUT THE PLAN IS TO EXPAND IN THE UPCOMING WEEKS. TOM MILLER, KCRA 3 NEWS. KELLIE: IT IS AMAZING TO SEE HOW THIS INDUSTRY HAS CHANGED. DID YOU GET A CHANCE TO TALK TO THE FOUNDER OF TAR RECORDS ON HOW HE THINKS THE MUSIC INDUSTRY IS HEADING?
